9/ The third milestone is increased local and state governance of autonomous vehicle technology (rather than federal oversight).
8/ By 2020, an estimated 75% of cars shipped globally (~69M vehicles) will be built with the necessary hardware to connect to the Internet.
7/ The second milestone will be persistent internet connectivity in cars & more sophisticated data management in the cloud.
6/ The first milestone will be whether we see the emergence of an aftermarket to retrofit existing vehicles for some autonomous capabilities

3/ "Modern automobiles" are the 300 baud modems for today's generation.
2/ It's fun to look at the 35 years of progress - and to try to identify the "inflection points" that led to mass adoption of the Internet.

10/ You can read our full, unedited quarterly letter to our institutional limited partners on this topic here: https://t.co/VsJ42DI586
9/ While @Firstround continues to actively invest in seed-stage companies, we think it’s important to be aware of the “market math”
8/ When people look at the “flow of funds” into the market, it is also important to look at the prices those funds are being deployed at.
7/ It appears that LPs and GPs are implicitly betting that exit values will indeed triple – otherwise industry returns will go down by 3x.
6/ Unless exit values also triple, a fund that generated a 3x return in 2007 would be just a 1x fund today. (Not rocket science – just math)
5/ Exit values (from both M&A and IPO), however, have not increased anywhere near the pace of entry values
4/ Entry prices continue to rise across all VC stages. The average seed stage valuation in 2015 will be almost 3x higher than it was in 2007
3/ The simple math of venture investing says that only two numbers determine an investment’s return: the entry price and the exit price.
2/ Some say we’re in a bubble – while other’s say we’re not.  While @Firstround doesn’t have a crystal ball, we do have a calculator.
1/ There’s been a good discussion recently about the state of tech startup/venture market recently. Our thoughts: https://t.co/VsJ42DI586

11/How many "private IPOs" are underwater now?  The low frequency of trading in these companies means we won't know for years.
10/And a third of the 2013 IPOs were underwater by end of the 2013 -  http://t.co/GbjmeZFSdI
9/More than 65% of 2011 IPOs were underwater before the end of 2011 - http://t.co/pinbiI3c2G
8/If there is one thing we can learn from the public IPO market, it's that our industry isn't always very good at pricing large companies.
7/By relying on private financing events as "comps", we risk pricing new financings (and creating new unicorns) based on stale valuations.
6/One negative of low frequency trading in private companies is the fact that prior financings are used as comps for other financings.
5/One benefit of low frequency trading in private companies is a long term focus - removing arbitrary time constraints for growth/profits.
4/IMO theres not enough focus on "low frequency trading". Public companies reprice daily. Private companies don't have to reprice for years.
3/I don't think we will fully understand the impact of the "private IPO" phenomenon for another 10 yrs - until after a full cycle plays out.
2/This stood out most to me: 231 co's raised $40M+ growth rounds in 2014 while just ~240 VC backed IT co's went public in the LAST 10 YEARS.
1/The data shared by @ttunguz deserves a lot of attention from tech investors (both early and late stage) & LPs.  http://t.co/YbFwgFGdmR

10/ Perhaps companies should keep a "ledger" of all of their debts - financial, technical, sales, marketing, hiring, etc?
9/ It's interesting to watch companies make rational tradeoffs (understanding the costs of speed) in their technical teams but not elsewhere
8/ Or "hiring debt" that comes from a hiring binge without investing in the management/cultural processes to make the new hires successful.
7/ For example, I frequently see companies incur "sales debt" by ramping up sales teams too fast, with incomplete scripts and process
6/ While it is explicitly understood that engineers might take shortcuts (& accrue debt), other functions don't have that same transparency.
5/ I'm surprised, however, that we don't frequently head about other "debts" that companies incur in the name of speed/growth.
4/ Not all technical debt is bad. Founders are used to working with their CTO to decide what technical debt to incur and when to repay it.
3/ These decisions are frequently known (and debated) in advance - and typically result in "interest payments" to repay the technical debt
2/ Companies often intentionally make decisions to incur technical debt to grow faster and achieve near-term goals.
1/ "Technical Debt" is a familiar concept in startups - ie, the tradeoffs from short-term decisions & underinvestment http://t.co/p61YyozZhd

8/ What else am I missing?
7/ While you would think a game company wants more gameplay, @Zynga chose to limit it.  (Results – avoid game saturation, increases LTV)
6/ @Path chose to limit number of friends to 150 (now 500).  (Result – limiting friends = more intimate/transparent discussion)
5/ Whereas @Pinterest allows external links w each Pin. (Result - users view Pinterest as collection of external content - unlike Instagram)
4/ Or @Instagram's decision not to allow any external links with their photos. (Result – Users consume all content in app)
3/ Or @Uber's decision not to let users schedule a pick up in advance (Result – Focus on 24/7 availability and liquidity)
2/ Like Twitter's decision not to have a read/unread count. (Result – No  notification saturation; users view tweets as ephemeral)
1/ Great products are often defined by small decisions. I've been trying to catalog contrarian product decisions and the impact they've had.
